bibl.title: Circular on Jesse W. Lazear's actions in Cuba, [1908?]

div1.p: This circular relates Lazear's role in the yellow fever research.

div1.head: Circular on Jesse W. Lazear's actions in Cuba, [1908?]
div1.opener:
Circular to be endorsed by Reed, Sternberg,
Trustees of university & c
and sent to Committee-
The Lazear Scholarship
div1.p:
On the 25th of September Jesse William Lazear, assistant-surgeon in the United
States army and a member of the government Commission for the investigation of yellow
fever lost his life from that disease at Quemados, Cuba. The circumstances leading
to this sad event were of a very unusual character. Lazear, a native of Baltimore
County, Maryland, a graduate of the Johns Hopkins University and of the medical de-
partment of Columbia University, New York, a highly educated physician, had pursued
important studies and investigations in Europe and in the laboratories of the Johns
Hopkins University in Baltimore. He was a member of the staff of the hospital and an
instructor in the University. In February 1900 he was induced by the opportunity for
research concerning malarial and yellow fevers to enter the United States army as
acting assistant-surgeon and was assigned especial laboratory duties at Columbia Bar-
racks near Havana. Later he was appointed by the Surgeon-general Sternberg a member
of the especial government Commission for the investigation of yellow fever. To the
brilliant discoveries of this Commission Lazear contributed largely, the investiga-
tions of this Commission leading them to the belief that a certain form of mosquito
played an important part in the transmission of the poison of yellow fever. A time
was reached, however, when the final proof of this hypothesis could only be determined
by direct experiment upon human beings. To this experiment Lazear and another member
of the Commission courageously subjected themselves. The latter acquired the disease
and recovered, Lazear escaped. Shortly afterwards, however, he repeated the experiment
allowing himself to be bitten by a mosquito from a yellow fever ward. He acquired
the disease which resulted fatally.

These two positive cases justified the Commission in making a preliminary report,
the conclusions of which have since then been entirely confirmed. This discovery
has brought about results of incalculable public importance. By demonstrating for the
first time the method by which yellow fever is acquired it has afforded us positive
(1)
and accurate means for protection of the public against the disease with the result
that in one year the city of Havana has been for the first time in its history entirely
free from this malady.

No sacrifice could be more deliberate or courageous than that of Lazear and the
great results which have followed should insure to his memory the lasting gratitude
of his fellow countrymen.

Dr. Lazear left a wife and two children in circumstances which oblige her to apply
for a pension. Surely no soldier dead in battle could deserve more from his country
than this man who by deliberately sacrificing his life has directly contributed to the
saving of thousands of others.
